thread.title: Anger towards Government WORSE than ever was against Fianna Fail - fury at Fine Gael 'protecting' Kenny
thread.title_full: Anger towards Government WORSE than ever was against Fianna Fail - fury at Fine Gael 'protecting' Kenny

author: Alana Fearon
title: Anger towards Government WORSE than ever was against Fianna Fail - fury at Fine Gael 'protecting' Kenny
text:
Anger towards Government WORSE than ever was against Fianna Fail - fury at Fine Gael 'protecting' Kenny 07:00, 24 Oct 2015 By Alana Fearon The majority of the rage is levelled at Taoiseach Enda Kenny as latest opinion poll reveals support for Fine Gael has dropped   Thanks   Colin Keegan, Collins Dublin Taoiseach Enda Kenny 
Public anger towards the Government is worse than it ever was against Fianna Fail — and the Taoiseach is public enemy No1, it’s been claimed. 
Community activists on the ground across the country say voter fury has reached boiling point just months from the election. 
And we can reveal the majority of the rage is being levelled at Enda Kenny. 
Sources claim Fine Gael are next in line when it comes to public fury, with Labour getting the least doorstep bashings – because voters have already decided the party is doomed. 
One activist revealed: “We thought it was bad pre-2011 when Fianna Fail were getting it in the neck. 
“Back then we’d never seen anything worse. People were livid and the bloodbath that ensued at the General Election was completely predicted. 
“But this is on another level. People are furious and while you’d think fury would be reserved for Labour, that’s not the case. 
“It’s Kenny people are gunning for.” Sam Boal/Rollingnews.ie An Tanaiste Joan Burton TD and An Taoiseach Enda Kenny TD 
One of the main causes of anger is that voters feel the Taoiseach is being protected by Fine Gael chiefs, who are shielding him from the public who elected him. 
The activist added: “The sense we’re getting is that people feel the Taoiseach is being wrapped in cotton wool and kept out of harm’s way when really they want answers. 
“For years it’s been Labour who’ve borne the brunt of voter anger and been accused of betraying those who put them in power. 
“But it seems now they can’t be bothered wasting their anger on Labour as they know the party is on the way to oblivion so now it’s Kenny and Fine Gael they’re baying for. 
“The dramatic shift to the left in the local elections last year was the public’s chance to get their own back after six years austerity and they’re waiting to unleash payback again. Stephen Collins/Collins Photos Taoiseach Enda Kenny at this year's Ploughing Championships 
“The economy might be improving and yes the Budget was undeniably positive for many, but people aren’t stupid.” 
The latest opinion poll revealed support for Fine Gael had dropped three points to 24%. 
Bizarrely, the Behaviour and Attitudes survey – which questioned voters for several days prior to the Budget – showed Labour support rose by two points to 8%. 
Fianna Fail were down one point on 19% and Sinn Fein were unchanged, also on 19%. 
Independents and others rose by one point to 29%. 
Fine Gael will be hoping the Budget can claw back public support ahead of the election scheduled for early spring. 
But after it was unveiled last week, Sinn Fein accused the Coalition of taking tips “straight out of the Fianna Fail handbook”. 
Sinn Fein tweeted the Budget was a lesson in “how to bribe people with their own money”.
